The Buddha asked Sudatta:
For those who stay at home, should they practice giving or not giving?
Sudatta said to the Buddha:
They should practice giving.
Should they give a lot?

The Buddha told Sudatta:

At that time, the eighty-four thousand kings who received the learning of wisdom, their minds and thoughts opened up, and they were all greatly delighted.

The eighty-four thousand minor kings each offered a white elephant adorned with gold and silver, a swift horse also adorned with gold and silver, a cow also adorned with gold and silver, a woman of exceptional beauty adorned with the seven precious substances and gorgeously attired, a golden bowl filled with silver grain, a silver bowl filled with golden grain, a lapis lazuli bowl filled with golden grain, a crystal bowl filled with golden grain, and a chariot made of gold adorned with the seven precious substances. The Buddha told Sudatta:
The Brahman Bilamba at that time is now me.
At that time, my giving was also good, and my mind was also good, but the recipient was not good. Although my giving was abundant, the reward I obtained was very little.

But now my Dharma is true, wonderful, pure, and my disciples are truly genuine. If one gives to a hundred srota-apanna people and the people of Jambudvipa given by Bilamba before, the reward obtained is not as good as giving to a single sakrdagamin person, whose merit is much greater than that.

Then Sudatta, having heard the Dharma, was overjoyed, and his body and mind became pure, attaining the path of the non-returner.
He only had five gold coins, and he would give one coin to the Buddha each day, one coin to the Dharma, one coin to the Sangha, use one coin for his own food, and keep one coin as capital;

He then accepted the five precepts and knelt, saying to the Buddha:
Today my lustful thoughts have been cut off, but how should I conduct myself while living at home?
The Buddha told Sudatta:
Just as your mind and thoughts are now pure and free from desire, you should return home and ask the women:
My desire has now ceased and is completely extinguished, without any further sexual activity. Each of you may do as you please.
Those who need a husband may follow your preferences. If you wish to stay here, I will provide you with clothing and food.
Sudatta accepted the teaching, bowed to the Buddha, and returned home to ask the women:

My desires are now completely extinguished and I have no further sexual thoughts. If any of you need a husband, each of you may do as you please. Those who wish to stay here will be provided with clothing and food without any shortage.
The women each did as they wished, following their preferences.

At that time, a woman was grinding grain to make flour. A ram came and dragged away the wheat flour. Unable to do anything about it, she grabbed a burning fire stick and beat the ram with it. The tip of the stick had fire that stuck to the sheep's wool. The sheep got hot from the fire and used it to rub against the elephant stable, causing the elephant stable to catch fire and burn the king's elephants. King Prasenajit ordered his ministers to set a limit, saying:
From now on, one should not light fires or lamps at night. Anyone who violates this will be fined one thousand ounces of gold.

At that time, Sudatta, having attained the Way, sat in meditation day and night at home. When it was time for meditation, he lit lamps and sat in meditation. At midnight, he rested. At cockcrow, he lit lamps again and sat in meditation.
The hunters caught him, seized the lamp, and brought it to the king, saying:
You should pay a fine.
Sudatta said to the king:

The king became angry and ordered him to be imprisoned, saying:

Sudatta replied:

At that time, the king saw firelight above the prison from the watchtower at night. The next day, the king immediately sent someone to tell Subhadra:
Sitting in the prison, you are shameless and continue to burn fire.
Subhadra replied:

He told Subhadra again:

At the beginning of the night, there were four fires. At midnight, there was one fire twice as big as the previous fire. At the end of the night, there was another fire that was even bigger than the previous one.

Subhadra replied:
These are not fires.

In the first watch of the night, the Four Heavenly Kings came down to see me. In the middle watch, the Heavenly Emperor of the Second Heaven came down to see me. In the last watch, the Seventh Brahma Heaven came down to see me. The light on these heavenly bodies is not fire.
When the messenger heard his words, he went back to report to the king. When the king heard this, he was startled and his hair stood on end.
The king said:
This person's blessings and virtues are extraordinary. How can I now humiliate him?
He then ordered the officer, saying:

He was then released.
Sudatta, having come out, went to where the Buddha was, bowed his head in reverence, and sat back to listen to the Dharma.

King Prasenajit then immediately had his carriage prepared and went to where the Buddha was. The people, seeing the king, all avoided their seats and stood up. Only Sudatta, his mind dwelling on the taste of the Dharma, did not rise when he saw the king.
The king's heart slightly resented this, thinking:

The Buddha told the king:

Why is it not the right time?
When people give rise to anger, resentment, and do not understand, if they give rise to greed and lust, indulge in women's beauty, are arrogant and self-important, and have no respectful mind;
When their minds are defiled and turbid, they cannot understand the wonderful Dharma when they hear it. For this reason, now is not the time to teach the Dharma to the king.
When the king heard the Buddha's words, he thought to himself:
Because of this person, I have lost two things today. I have become angry and cannot hear the Dharma.
He bowed to the Buddha and left. When he got outside, he ordered his attendants:

Having said this, at that moment, tigers, wolves, lions, and other poisonous and harmful beasts all came and surrounded the king on all sides.
Seeing this, the king became greatly frightened and returned to where the Buddha was.
The Buddha asked the great king:

The king said to the Buddha:

The Buddha told the king:

The king said:

The Buddha said:

If he had not returned, the king would have certainly been in danger and would not have been able to escape.
Hearing the Buddha's words, the king became greatly frightened. He immediately repented towards Sudatta and bowed to him, spreading out the sheepskin on the ground in front of Sudatta.
